results.title: Pitjiri: the snake that will not sink
results.creator_credit: Karen Hughes and Trikon Film Corporation
results.brief_description: In 1936 on a remote outpost in the Northern Territory, nine aboriginal elders appeared before Ruth Heathcock, a young white nurse who they believed was a member of their tribe before the Dreaming. What she later experienced in her healing work is the subject of this extraordinary documentary. A multi-award winning production.
results.title_for_label: Pitjiri: the snake that will not sink
results.description: In 1936 on a remote outpost in the Northern Territory, nine aboriginal elders appeared before Ruth Heathcock, a young white nurse who they believed was a member of their tribe before the Dreaming. What she later experienced in her healing work is the subject of this extraordinary documentary. A multi-award winning production.

results.title: Pitcha this : youth telling stories : Digital Storytelling project
results.creator_credit: Teialah Mason, Simone Andy, Rebecca Phillips, Nikki Butler, Lionel Austin, Kalimna Andy, Jade Colgan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Seven Indigenous youth tell their own stories about who they are and where they come from. They proudly describe the places and people that inspire them and connect them to their heritage. In doing so, they provide an examination of what it is to grow up Indigenous in Australia in the 1990s, how to engage with your spirituality and identity today.
results.title_for_label: Pitcha this : youth telling stories : Digital Storytelling project
results.creator_credit_for_label: Teialah Mason, Simone Andy, Rebecca Phillips, Nikki Butler, Lionel Austin, Kalimna Andy, Jade Colgan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Pitcha this : Stories from the windy wanderers : Digital Storytelling workshop
results.brief_description: Nine stories from members of the Indigenous community in Heywood in south-western Victoria. The stories, while providing an insight into the treatment of Indigenous people in Australia, are mostly personal accounts of what it is that keeps these particular people spiritually connected, whether it be the land or the people they love.

results.title: Pitcha this : memories of Fitzroy : Foundation for Young Australians : Digital Storytelling project
results.creator_credit: May Andy, Marlene Scerri, Kelvin Onus-King, Howard Edwards, Frances Gallagher, Deborah Deacon, Arika Waulu, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Seven Indigenous leaders in the community tell of growing up in Fitzroy. From disperate backgrounds, they have all become heavily involved with the activism and community spirit of Fitzroy in Melbourne, to grow into inspirational leaders for generations to come. Here they share their experiences and passions, as well as the families and communities they love.
results.title_for_label: Pitcha this : memories of Fitzroy : Foundation for Young Australians : Digital Storytelling project
results.creator_credit_for_label: May Andy, Marlene Scerri, Kelvin Onus-King, Howard Edwards, Frances Gallagher, Deborah Deacon, Arika Waulu, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Pitcha this : life stories from A.S.H.E (Shepparton) : Digital Storytelling project
results.creator_credit: Natasha Craig, Troy Lovett, Chris Mansfield, Daniel McCrimmon, Brian Beckhurst, Misty Briggs, Joel Atkinson, Tammy-Lee Atkinson, Helen Atkinson, VicHealth, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Nine stories of the lives of students from Shepparton’s A.S.H.E (Academy of Sport, Health and Education), as created by the students as part of ACMI’s Digital Storytelling program. These students, also members of the Indigenous community, tell of their loves, ambitions and, mostly, of the family that support and sustain them.

results.title: Pitcha this : just our mob from Gippsland : Digital Storytelling project
results.creator_credit: Karen Milward, Norman Terrick, Linda Kennedy-Baxter, Emily Yarram, Daphne Yarram, Bindie Jack, Bess Yarram, Ben Yarram, Barbara Tilley, Amy Dowd, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ten members of the Gippsland Indigenous community share their stories. The stories, while biographical in form, are mostly centred on the theme of family, of belonging in a community and how both these things contribute to a sense of identity.

results.title: Pitch black = Nightfall
results.creator_credit: David Twohy, Tom Engelman and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Pitch black is a futuristic science fiction thriller filmed on location outside Coober Pedy, Australia. It includes Australian actors Radha Mitchell, Lewis Fitz-Gerald, Claudia Black, and John Moore. The story begins with a spacecraft crashing onto an unknown plant. The few that have survived must band together in an attempt to live through the unknown dangers the plant hides. Initially, the group’s concerns are for water, shelter and the threat of murderer, Riddick (Vin Diesel), who has also survived the crash. However, when one of the group is killed and its leader, Fry (Radha Mitchell), is nearly killed also, the group concedes they must enlist the help of Riddick in order to survive. Still unsure of what the new danger is, the group prepares themselves as best they can, only to find when night falls that nothing could have prepared them for what comes out of the darkness.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Twohy, Tom Engelman and Universal Pictures

results.title: Pistol opera
results.creator_credit: Seijun Suzuki, Satoru Ogura, Katashima Ikki, Television Tokyo Channel 12, Shochiku, Ogura Jimusyo, Eisei Gekijo Company and Dentsu
results.brief_description: In the late 60s, Seijun Suzuki developed a cult following with his re-envisioning of B-grade Japanese gangster flicks, defying the tropes of the genre with his desultory approach to narrative and imaginative stylistics. Here, freed of convention, Suzuki explores the possibilities of his art with astoundingly colourful and inventive vignettes that track the movements of Miyuki Minazuki, (also known as stray cat) a beautiful female assassin who dresses in black (with heels) and is determined to be number one amid her peers. This quest requires her to face down her many formidable foes and do battle, depicted in a series of extraordinarily beautiful tableaux. Stray cat must also deal with her lover and boss, a mysterious woman with whom she shares an explosive relationship. Absurdist and dreamily hallucinatory filmmaking, investigates shadowy, irrational aspects of desire. Somewhere between a remake and a sequel to Suzuki’s own cult movie “Branded to Kill” (1967). Cast includes Makiko Esumi, Sayoko Yamaguchi, Kan Hanae, Masatoshi Nagase, Mikijiro Hira, Kirin Kiki.
